citation.article-title: Genomic and phenotypic characterization of Xanthomonas cynarae sp. nov., a new species that causes bacterial bract spot of artichoke (Cynara scolymus L.).
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Xanthomonas cynarae sp. nov.
Xanthomonas cynarae (cy.na.rae. L. fem. gen. n. cynara from genus name of artichoke, Cynara scolymus L.)
Typical symptoms caused by Xanthomonas cynarae consist of water-soaked then dark green spots which occur on the abaxial part of the capitulum bracts.
As the infection progresses, large brown necrosis spots result.
Bacterial cells are Gram-negative, non-sporeforming, straight rods, motile by one polar flagellum.
Colonies grown on YBGA for 2 d at 28 °C are circular (2 mm in diameter), smooth, glistening, slightly convex and produce the yellow xanthomonadin pigment.
They do not produce cytochrome c oxidase, nitrate reductase, urease or indole.
They hydrolyse casein, gelatin and aesculin, but not starch.
Acid is produced from galactose, glucose and mannose, but not from arabinose, erythritol, inositol or sorbitol.

Using BIOLOG GN microplates, Xanthomonas cynarae gives metabolic activity on the following carbon substrates: dextrin, glycogen, Tween 40, Tween 80, N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, cellobiose, D-fructose, L-fucose, D-galactose, gentiobiose, α-D-glucose, lactulose, maltose, D-mannose, D-melibiose, D-psicose, D-raffinose, sucrose, D-trehalose, turanose, methylpyruvate, monomethylsuccinate, acetic acid, citric acid, α-hydroxybutyric acid, α-ketobutyric acid, α-ketoglutaricacid, DL-lacticacid,succinicacid, bromosuccinic acid, succinamic acid, alaninamide, D-alanine, L-alanine, L-asparagine, L-aspartic acid, L-glutamic acid, glycyl-glutamic acid, histidine, proline, L-serine, threonine, urocanic acid, uridine, glycerol, DL-α-glycerophosphate and glucose 1-phosphate.

It lacks metabolic activity on: α-cyclodextrin, N-acetyl-D- galactosamine, adonitol, L-arabinose, D-arabitol, meso-inositol, D-mannitol, L-rhamnose, xylitol, formic acid, D-galactonic acid lactone, D-galacturonic acid, D-gluconic acid, D-glucosaminic acid, D-glucuronic acid, propionic acid, quinic acid, D-saccharic acid, glucuronamide, L-leucine, L-ornithine, L-phenylalanine, L-pyroglutamic acid, D-serine, DL-carnitine, γ-aminobutyric acid, thymidine, phenyl ethylamine, putrescine and 2-aminoethanol. Xanthomonas cynarae induces a hypersensitive reaction on tobacco leaves.
Strains pathogenic to artichoke (Cynara scolymus L.) give typical symptoms after inoculation on detached scarified bracts.
The DNA G­+C content is 63 mol%.
The type strain is CFBP 4188T and has been deposited in the Collection Française de Bactéries Phytopathogénes (CFBP), Angers, France.
